Attention HILR Members

The Curriculum Committee is not currently accepting proposals. The date for new proposal submission will be posted on the HILR Community Website. Please contact a member of the Curriculum Committee if you have questions.

item.title: Notes for Co-Chairs
item.dc:creator: hilradmin
item.content:encoded:
CCsubmit Admin Notes for Co-Chairs

Co Chair Oversight (excerpts from Help column in CCsubmit)

Notify Steven Cabral (scabral@g.harvard.edu) of all changes in the Committee membership. All members must have their own accounts with the correct roles for the system to operate correctly. Previous member’s accounts remain in the system for archive purposes but are inaccessible to them.

At the start of a new term, review any deferred proposals. This requires administrative attention from the co-chairs to assure that the term is set correctly when the proposal is deferred. Provide a list of these deferred proposals to Steven C. He will make sure they appear in the next term’s list. Note whether the proposal is already approved. If not, Steven will restart the workflow so you can assign a sponsor in the new term. (This may be the previous sponsor; your choice.) Deferred proposals will then appear, after administrative updates for the new term. Someone (co-chair, or the previous sponsor) must check with the proposer to verify books and reading, preparation time, day, time, and course size selections. 

When a proposal is submitted, one of the co-chairs must assign it a sponsor. Proposals that require your attention or action will be in your Inbox. All active proposals will be available under Active Proposals. Once proposals start to be submitted, you should log into CCsubmit at least daily, check your Inbox, and monitor the review comments and workflow for Active Proposals. Sponsors who leave proposals in Modification by Sponsor will need a reminder to complete the edit.

When you act on a proposal, be sure to enter a Workflow Note in the box in the top right of the screen stating the reason for your action.  This is essential for understanding later why a proposal has changed status.

Before an approved proposal can proceed to Tess for the catalog, the sponsor must make any final edits from the voting meeting. Co-chairs should monitor proposals that were approved to make sure these edits were properly done. Both co-chairs must then review each proposal.

Always use CHROME to access the Administrative functions.

Assigning a Sponsor

Click on the proposal title in your Inbox.  Scroll down to the Sponsor box and select a sponsor from the committee member list.

Go in order by first name; if there are exceptions –e.g., you do not want to assign a difficult proposal to a new member–keep careful track of whom the next person will be for a proposal assignment.

If you make any changes in the original proposal – e.g., you correct a misspelling in the title–indicate the change in the Workflow Note box.

Be sure to hit Submit after a sponsor has been assigned and any changes made to the proposal.

When you have done so, it will say Review by Committee in the Workflow column in your Inbox.

Do not use the Workflow Controls at the bottom right side of the screen. If you do not know how to do something with a proposal, contact Dick Rubinstein.

Using the Administrative Menu to Solve Common Problems

Go to the Administrative column on the right side of the screen and scroll down to the last two entries, All Proposals and Drafts.  These are the sections you will use in solving most problems.

Problem: An SGL thought he/she submitted a proposal but received no answer.

Ask the SGL if he/she clicked the [Save and Continue Later] button (or might have). If that’s what happened, go to Drafts in the Administrative column, open drafts, until you find one from the proposer. If you do, send the SGL a link to the draft[RR1] . *You have to find the right draft. There may be none if the proposer did not create a draft. You cannot complete the proposal because it may have errors in it and is probably not the one the proposer wants to submit anyway. [RR2] 

Problem: An SGL decides to defer his/her proposal.

The solution to this problem requires breaking the workflow. If you’ve not done this before, or are unsure about it, please contact Dick to walk you through it.

Use this chart to determine the correct remedy.

Problem: A proposal is withdrawn or just a mistake.

The solution to this problem requires breaking the workflow. If you’ve not done this before, or are unsure about it, please contact Dick to walk you through it.

Use this chart to determine the correct remedy.

Problem: A committee member has inadvertently moved a proposal to Ready to Vote. 

The proposal should be in Ready to Vote. If the proposal is not there, this is not the problem. Click on Act on this Proposal (upper left side of screen).  Send it back to the Sponsor by clicking on the Send to Sponsor button.  

Problem: You need to know the most recent action on a proposal, which could include any comments Tess makes in her review. 

Go to All Proposals and open the proposal.  Click on Act on this Proposal and scroll to the bottom of the screen where you will see the timeline with the latest status. Since there is no Cancel button on this screen, use the browser Back button or another tab (such as Inbox) to leave the screen without making a change. Only hit Submit if you’ve made a change to the proposal[RR3] .

Other Problems: 

If a proposal no longer appears in Proposals Under Review, it may be being edited by the Sponsor.  You can check the status of all current proposals in Active Proposals.

If you need to see a previous version of a proposal, they are kept in a CCsubmit archive. Jen or Steven C can help in retrieving the proposal from the archive.

If you have a problem you cannot solve, contact Dick for help.

FAQ

Q: Does “send a link to him” mean hit Submit? When submitting a proposal, [Submit] will send a copy of the proposal to the first proposer. If they entered their email wrong, it won’t happen, of course. But the proposal will be in the system, so you can acknowledge receipt and fix the email address. [Save and Continue Later] won’t send an email if the user doesn’t provide a (correct) eMail address. Don’t use the word “Submit” to mean “save a draft.” That’ll confuse people.

** The submitter should always do the submit, never a CC member. Send a link to the draft by email. (Copy and paste the link from the listing of drafts, once you’ve identified the correct one.) Note that anyone with this link can edit or submit the proposal, so be careful to send the right link.

 [RR1]Your question: Does send a link to him mean hit Submit? [Submit] will send a copy of the proposal to the first proposer. If they entered their email wrong, it won’t happen, of course. But the proposal will be in the system, so you can acknowledge receipt and fix the email address. [Save and Continue Later] won’t send an email if the user doesn’t provide a (correct) eMail address. Don’t use the word “Submit” to mean “save a draft.” That’ll confuse people.

 [RR2]The submitter should always do the submit, never a CC member. Send a link to the draft by email. [RR3]I’ve added a request for a Cancel button to our feature request list.

item.title: Help
item.dc:creator: hilradmin
item.content:encoded:
General

CCsubmit is HILR’s system for submitting, reviewing, editing, and publishing course proposals.

  • HILR Members can submit their proposals by going to ccsubmit.com.
  • Proposals that are not complete may be saved as drafts. Drafts do not enter the proposal workflow until they are submitted by the proposer.
  • Members of the Curriculum Committee can log in to the system by going to ccsubmit.com/cc. If you have a problem logging in, please contact one of the CC co-chairs or Steven Cabral.
  • If you have difficulties, or don’t know how to accomplish something, please ask the co-chairs or email Dick Rubinstein. Please don’t struggle.

Views of Proposals

How a proposal is presented on the screen is determined by how you get to it. To say this another way, the activity you’re performing on a proposal determines how you view it. There are four views:

1.     Commenting on a proposal: Read the proposal and previous comments, then add your own.

2.     Reviewing a proposal that will be voted on. Editing or commenting are not possible in this view.

3.     Editing a proposal: If you’re the sponsor or co-chair, you can make changes to the proposal content.

4.     Acting on a proposal: You can move a proposal to the next step in the workflow, for example, as the sponsor, you can send it to the co-chairs to be voted upon.

If you are viewing a proposal, and want to edit it or act on it, check out the links at the top left of the screen. For example, there may be a link to Edit this proposal, or to Act on this proposal. These links will take you to the correct screen.

Committee Members

When a proposal is assigned to you as the sponsor, you will receive an email from the system. Your proposals, when they are under review or require your action, will be in your Inbox on CCsubmit. Once proposals start to be submitted, you should log into CCsubmit at least daily, check on the proposals you sponsor, and also provide review comments for all other Proposals Under Review. Note that to provide review comments, you must access the proposal through the Proposals Under Review tab. Prior to a meeting, please review Proposals Ready for Vote, accessing them through that tab. If you do not see a proposal in the above menus, you can find its status under Active Proposals.

When, as sponsor, you need to edit a proposal, open it from your Inbox, then click the [Edit] button. When you are editing, the proposal is not available for commenting by the committee. Thus, it is important to complete the edit process.

  • Add a Workflow Note, summarizing your edit. Did you fix a specific problem? Just typos? Major revision? Committee members need to know this to understand what’s changed in the proposal.
  • To end editing and continue Committee commenting without special notice, click .
  • To end editing and continue Committee commenting, and also send an email announcement of the edit to Committee members, click

Committee Co-chairs

  • Notify Steven Cabral of all changes in the Committee membership. All Committee Members must have their own accounts with the correct roles for the system to operate correctly. When CC members leave the committee, their accounts remain, but their roles and logins are eliminated. This is necessary to preserve history in the system.
  • At the start of a new term, the co-chairs should review any deferred proposals. (They appear automatically, after administrative updates for the new term.) Someone (you, or the previous sponsor) must check with the proposer to verify reading, preparation time, day, time, and course size selections. Note that deferred proposals may or may not have been voted upon.
  • When a proposal is submitted, one of the co-chairs must assign it a sponsor. Proposals that require your attention or action will be in your Inbox on CCsubmit. All active proposals will be available under Active Proposals. Once proposals start to be submitted, you should log into CCsubmit at least daily, check your Inbox, and also monitor the review comments for Proposals Under Review.
  • A proposal that no longer appears as in Proposals Under Review may be being edited by the sponsor. You can check the status of all current proposals in Active Proposals.
  • To defer a proposal to a later term, edit it and change the Semester. Do not change any other fields.
  • To remove a proposal from further consideration, there are two steps:
    • Act on the proposal, and force it into the Tabling workflow step.
    • Edit it, and change its Proposal Status to either Withdrawn or Mistake, as appropriate. The proposal will disappear from the workflow. The Admin can reinstate such a proposal, if necessary.
  • When you act on a proposal, be sure to enter a Workflow Note, stating the action and your reason. This is our audit trail, and is essential to understanding later why a proposal has changed status.
  • Previous versions of proposals are kept in a CCsubmit archive. Though it requires some administrative effort, a previous version of a proposal (i.e. the CD) can be recovered by the admin.
  • Before an Approved proposal can proceed to Tess for the catalog, both co-chairs must review it.
  • If you do not know how to accomplish a task, don’t struggle or experiment. Contact Dick Rubinstein for help.
